title: Who might John Lennon have been referring to when he sang, 'Who in the hell d'you think you are? A super star? Well, right you are!' on his song 'Instant Karma'? - Quora

response.answer_text: John is singing to EVERYONE! The theme of the song is that we’re all stars—famous or not. This was one of John’s most positive songs—”WE ALL SHINE ON.” “Karma” refers to a person’s deeds across a cycle of lifetimes, and to their consequences for that person’s spiritual fate. John knew that “Instant Karma,” then, is a contradiction in terms. But John loved the idea of selling “Instant Karma” like it was instant coffee. He was fascinated by advertising and slogan songs. In London, John wrote the song in a single morning, skipping the Beatles recording session in which the Beatles completed Paul’s “Let It Be.” Phil Spector was in London to talk to Allen Klein about producing “Let It Be.” John called him up and said, “Come over to Abbey Road. I’ve just written a monster.” John quickly got a band together consisting of George Harrison, Klaus Voormann and Alan White. John played the piano and sang. From the day John wrote it to the day the single charted was 10 days—one of the fastest released songs ever. John believed that every human being had the potential for spiritual greatness. And he believed that we should all take responsibility for the fate of the world. John believed that he could change people’s minds with music. He said that the essence of “Instant Karma” was to breathe belief into people. “All we’re trying to say in the world is that you’re gonna be great,” he said. WE ALL SHINE ON, LIKE THE MOON AND THE STARS AND THE SUN.

John reportedly told Alice Cooper that Instant Karma was about Paul. Can't remember where I read this offhand, but it makes sense reading the lyrics, given his anger at that time and the fact that quite a few of their songs were directed at each other, or about what was going on in their lives, particularly in this period. I'm sure he intended it to have universal meaning as well and not be too obvious.
